content: Prior to the passage of SAFETEA, the Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century (TEA-21) provided funds for federal highway, highway safety, and transit programs from FY1998-FY2003. After October 1, 2003, short-term extension acts were used to continue federal surface transportation programs, causing uncertainty in the highway and transit community. Long-term reauthorizations, like TEA-21, are preferred for better long-term planning and construction of infrastructure. The passage of SAFETEA brought relief to the highway and transit community, which had faced uncertainty due to short-term extensions. SAFETEA, originally intended as a six-year bill, was passed as a four-year bill expiring in FY2009.
